pageContext.description:
These two portraits were probably painted to commemorate the death of John the Steadfast of Saxony (1468-1532), in 1532. He is paired with his predecessor and brother, the Elector Frederick III of Saxony (1463-1525), who was Cranach's most important early patron. 
[Sotheby's online database; http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2008/old-master-paintings-day-sale-l08034/lot.105.html?locale=en; accessed 20-03-2019]

metadata.title: Portrait of the  Elector Frederick III of Saxony, called the Wise (1463 - 1525)

pageContext.provenance:
- Ambras collection, Innsbruck 
- Herr Halbreuter, Munich, on whose behalf sold by G. Joseph Esq, Bond Street, to Carl Haag (1820-1915) in 1862 [1]
- thence by descent to the former owner
- 10.07.2008 sold by Sotheby's. London
[1]Carl Haag (1820-1915) was a very notable painter of Orientalist subject matter. [...] Haag also owned another pair of small panels from Cranach's studio, which are the previous lot in this sale.
[Sotheby's online database; http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2008/old-master-paintings-day-sale-l08034/lot.105.html?locale=en; accessed 20-03-2019]
pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia at left side above shoulder: serpent with elevated wings, facing right and dated '1532'; in black paint
[cda 2019]
